content: Basic operations
Here are the operations that you will learn once you finish this lecture:
Most of the operations shown below are applied to vectors in $ \mathbb {R}^2 $, but they can be also applied to vectors in $ \mathbb {R}^3 $ and any $ \mathbb {R}^n $.
Vector addition
You can add two vectors quite easily by simply adding their $x$ coordinates together, and adding their $y$ coordinates together.
To add the vectors $ \vec {v_1} = (x_1, \ y_1) $ and $ \vec {v_2} = (x_2, \ y_2) $, use the following formula:
Vector addition may look different depending on the type of vector.
Both graphs display the two vectors being added together: $ \vec {v_1} + \vec {v_2} = (2 + 2, \ 3 + 2) = (4, \ 5) $

content: Note that $ \vec {v_1} + \vec {v_2} $ starts at $ (0, \ 0) $ for the algebraic representation, contrary to the geometrically represented one, which starts at the start of $ \vec {v_1} $ and ends at the end of $ \vec {v_2} $.
Notation
There is a special notation that you might see when two geometric vectors are added with a similar point. When adding them, the sum vector has the "inner" point removed ($B$ in this case):
$ \vec {AB} + \vec {BC} = \vec{A \cancel {B}} + \vec{\cancel {B} C}  = \vec {AC} $
Again, this only occurs if the "inner" points are the same.

Scalar multiplication
You can multiply a scalar value $k$ to a vector. This is done by multiplying $k$ by both the $x$ and $y$ values.
Here is the formula for such operation with the vector $ \vec {v} = (x, \ y) $:
$ k \vec {v} = (kx, \ ky) $
Visually, this looks like you are multiplying the magnitude (length) of the vector:
The elongation of the vector is the same for both geometric and algebraic vectors
Dot product
The dot product of two vectors is the length of the projection of one vector onto the other. Now this sound a bit complicated, but once you see what it really looks like it makes total sense!
However, before doing so, let's look at the formula to obtain the dot product of two vectors $ \vec {v_1} = (x_1, \ y_1) $ and $ \vec {v_2} = (x_2, \ y_2) $ :
The visualization of the dot product is the same for geometric and algebraic vectors
Please note that the dot product is a scalar. It is the included in the magnitude of the vector, NOT the vector itself!
Alternate formula
There is another way to calculate the dot product, and it involves the magnitudes of both vectors, as well as the angle between them:
$ \vec {v_1} \ \cdot \ \vec {v_2} = \left \| \vec {v_1} \right \| \left \| \vec {v_2} \right \| \cos \theta $
Dot product of orthogonal vectors
The dot product of two orthogonal (perpendicular) vectors is equal to $0$.
For two orthogonal vectors $ \vec {n} $ and $ \vec {m} $:
$ \vec {n} \ \cdot \ \vec {m} = 0 $

This is because the angle between both vectors is $ 90^o $, and the value of $ \cos \theta $ when $ \theta = 90^o $ in $ \vec {n} \ \cdot \ \vec {m} = \left \| \vec {v_1} \right \| \left \| \vec {v_2} \right \| \cos \theta $ equals $0$.
Cross product
The cross product is used in $ \mathbb {R}^3 $, and it produces a new vector that is orthogonal (or perpendicular) to the two vectors used.
Calculating the cross product can be complicated, so we will try to simplify it for you.

content: Scalar cross product
You can calculate the magnitude of the cross product vector by using the following formula:
$ \vec {a} \times \vec {b} = | \ \vec {a} \ | | \ \vec {b} \ | \sin \theta $
The angle between two vectors
You can determine the angle between two vectors by using the two formulas for the dot product that we just learned:
$ \frac {\vec {v_1} \ \cdot \ \vec {v_2}} {\left \| \vec {v_1} \right \| \left \| \vec {v_2} \right \|} = \cos \theta $

The projection of one vector onto another
The vector projection of $ \vec {v_1} $ onto $ \vec {v_2} $ is a vector that is in the same direction as $ \vec {v_2} $, but same magnitude as the dot product of $ \vec {a} $ and $ \vec {b} $.
It has its own special notation $ \text {proj}_{\vec {v_2}} {\vec {v_1}} $ indicated a projection of $ \vec {v_1} $ onto $ \vec {v_2} $.
To calculate the projection of some vector $ \vec {a} $ onto $ \vec {b} $, use the following formula:
$ \text {proj}_{\vec {b}} {\vec {a}} = (\frac { \vec {a} \ \cdot \ \vec {b} } {\vec {b} \ \cdot \ \vec {b}}) \vec {b} $
scalar projection
The scalar projection is the magnitude of the projection vector and it is obtained from the following formula:
$ | \ \text {proj}_{\vec {b}} \vec {a} \ | = \frac {| \ \vec {a} \ \cdot \ \vec {b} \ |} {| \ \vec {b} \ |} $
